• Pittsburgh Water announced it is pausing four flood mitigation projects citywide due to funding shortfalls, including the Four Mile Run project that has been in development for six years

• The paused projects are Four Mile Run, Stewart Avenue, MLK Field, and South Side Park - with Four Mile Run being the most critical due to severe flooding that fills the neighborhood with sewage when heavy rains occur

• Pittsburgh Water has spent $8.7 million on the Four Mile Run project design, which is now 90% complete, but needs an additional $30 million for construction

• The project lost $10 million in funding from Alcasan when green infrastructure elements (stream daylighting) were removed due to permitting challenges with the state and CSX railroad

• Pittsburgh Water's $1.2 billion capital improvement plan over five years prioritizes mandated projects like the Water Reliability Plan (30% of funding) and lead service line replacement over stormwater projects

• Recent improvements to the M-29 outfall may have helped reduce flooding, but Pittsburgh Water is conducting hydraulic modeling to confirm the impact since no major storms have occurred since 2021

• Army Corps of Engineers representatives outlined potential federal funding programs that could provide 75% reimbursement for flood mitigation work if Pittsburgh Water applies

• Council Member Warwick expressed frustration that residents who fought against the Mon Oakland Connector road project now see their flood project canceled, calling it a crisis of faith in government

• Pittsburgh Water committed to completing analysis of recent improvements and exploring grant funding options before holding a community meeting in Four Mile Run

• The proclamation marks the 57th anniversary of the federal Fair Housing Act, passed on April 11, 1968, which prohibits housing discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, national origin, disability, or family status.

• Pittsburgh has stronger protections than federal law — the city banned housing discrimination in 1958 under Mayor David Lawrence, 10 years before the federal act.

• Pittsburgh's fair housing law also covers discrimination based on ancestry, gender identity, gender expression, place of birth, sexual orientation, domestic violence survivor status, citizenship, preferred language, and hairstyle.

• Council committed to supporting city departments and residents in fighting housing discrimination and working toward fair housing goals.

• Human Relations Commission staff attended the meeting and emphasized that housing is a human right and that fair housing work happens year-round, not just during the proclamation month.

• The commission noted increased threats to fair housing rights nationally and reaffirmed their commitment to enforcement.

• International groups in 2022 and 2023 called on U.S. officials to better address housing discrimination that harms vulnerable populations.

*   Federal law bans housing discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, and other factors. Pittsburgh's local ordinance adds protections for gender identity, sexual orientation, and status as a survivor of domestic violence, among others.
*   Representatives from the city's Human Relations Commission accepted the proclamation, emphasizing that "housing is a human right" and a basic survival need, not just a slogan.

• Pittsburgh City Council unanimously approved a resolution declaring April 22, 2025 as "Charles Chuck Cooper Day" to honor the basketball pioneer who broke racial barriers.

• Chuck Cooper became the first African American drafted into the NBA on April 25, 1950, when the Boston Celtics selected him as the 14th overall pick.

• Cooper was born in Pittsburgh in 1926, graduated from Westinghouse High School in 1944, and served in the U.S. Navy during World War II.

• At Duquesne University, Cooper was an All-American who started all four years, set a school record with 990 total points in four seasons, and helped his team achieve a 78-19 record.

• During his NBA career, Cooper played 409 games, scored 2,725 points, grabbed 2,431 rebounds, and recorded 733 assists.

• After basketball, Cooper continued breaking barriers as the first Black city department director in Pittsburgh in 1970, serving as Parks and Recreation director and later working as a banking executive.

• Cooper was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 2019 and has two buildings named after him at Duquesne University.

• His son established the Chuck Cooper Foundation in 2013, which has awarded $400,000 in scholarships and runs youth outreach programs.

• The proclamation celebrates Cooper's commitment to community service, military service, and shattering racial barriers both in sports and corporate America.
